It all depends on your scope and target plattform. there are alot of Shadow techniques and you always have to balance between quality and performance. With every shadowcasting light and each cascade you have to draw each shadow caster is an additional drawcall. there are some optimisations for batching but that requires alot of work for the asset creation and level art. On our private project we build a topdown open world RPG for Mobile. There we have different requirements. Save Drawcalls and minimize the shader complexity. WRITING.TEXT: If you ask yourself why the hell hexfields and not the Unity Terrain? I tryed to Optimize Landscape Rendering by assuming that I render a max of 3Tiles on a Landscape Transition. Because I dont need LODing or something else I decidet to use Displaces Meshes.I Used Houdini to generate the Hexfields out of a Landscape from Houdini. this is such a Huge Task.

Good Approach but you dont need to downsample it. Because Vram is not an issue anymore and you sample the buffer anyways per pixel the downsample performance improvement ist only Useful when rendering Post FX and doing calculations such as blur or depth comparison. Because downsampling is there fore 2 reasons save VRam and save calculations on pixel base. the Downsampling in this case makes the Water ripples just bad. And once you render the Water Post Opaque you can simply sample the screenbuffer after the opaque pass with full res. One thing is you could have used is Planar reflections and reduce the capture resolution by 2 or 3. Because a camera capture have to do a few things per pixel. but there are also the Drawcalls relevant. You could set a rendermask to the objects that are most prominent to the Image. Like the Colored blocks or the Landscape in the background.

Totally got your point. but it is not required. Once you sample the Screenbuffer of the opaque passes your good to go, so you require no extra vram ;-) the other thing. Reflection captures are Spherical and lead to bad Reflections on big surfaces like lakes. the others are Parralx corrected cubemaps and they are relatively expensive. When implementing Planar reflections with a verry low Resolution like 512x512 your imagequality will be so much betten and the overhead is minimal when you optimize your drawcalls. I just want to help you on this I have worked on optimization for Mobile on multiple Games one of them was Sacred Legends. that was before SRP or URP was on the horizon. On Mobile the bottleneck is not the VRam it is the bandwith and the processing power. and with open GL:ES2 to 3.5 its the Drawcall data that costs the most performance. and Vulkan is yet not supported on all Mobile platforms. Thats at least my experience.

You can still Use Cubemap reflections for the other assets. Just disable the Reflectionprobes for the Waterplane. The other objects can still use it. We implemented the feature for the iPhone 4+ so It is not that expensive. The Camera is Just Refect the Orientation trough the surface normal. [http://web.cse.ohio-state.edu/\~shen.94/781/Site/Slides\_files/reflection.pdf](http://web.cse.ohio-state.edu/~shen.94/781/Site/Slides_files/reflection.pdf) Dont checked if it is the right one but it looks valid

yes planar for the water. and cubemap for the rest. how many cobemaps is not relevant. since I expect you to do forward rendering the complexity scales linea to the resolution of the screen. so setting the gameres to 2/3 of your devices res already helps. It even samples subpixels and give a smooter end result. But always keep in mind everything that is reflected by the planar reflection is rendered twice. you also can use a shader override for the reflection and use a less expensive tech like only diffuse and global cubemap ect. That should give you a good aproximation of what is reflected but save a ton of performance.
